prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band-3, RA~10, radio AGN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal is for Band-3 continuum imaging of 2 low-excitation radio galaxies, to directly detect thermal emission from the hot accretion flow. The aim is to determine the continuum flux density, and to compare these as a function of radio jet power (also with 5 other sources in a separate science goal). The required sensitivity is estimated to provide a S/N~10. The sources will be unresolved.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our focus is on continuum observations, and therefore we propose to use the low spectral resolution TDM mode. As such, the data rate is relatively low, and no further averaging is required (or desired).

The angular scale of the hot accretion disk around these AGN will be unresolved with ALMA. We aim for a moderately high angular resolution, to avoid any contamination from any thermal emission from extended dust in the galaxies, whilst avoiding angular resolutions so high that the calibration overhead begins to increase significantly. 0.5 arcsec resoluton (few hundred parsec at these redshifts) offers an ideal compromise, and is a resolution that can be matched at all three observing frequencies that we propose. The relevant array configurations are also scheduled when our targets would be night-time targets, increasing the likelihood of suitable observing conditions.

Estimates of the synchrotron luminosity associated with the thermal electron population of the ADAF have been made by many authors. Figure 1 of Yuan & Narayan (2014) shows example SEDs for best-model parameters (of disk viscosity, magnetic pressure, ion-to-electron energy transfer efficiency, and efficiency of disk winds). They indicate that for a black hole of 2e9 solar masses, accreting with a bolometric luminosity of 1e-4 of the Eddington luminosity (the properties of our tartgets) then the expected nu-L_nu is 5e39 erg/s at 3.1mm. This is in line with the results from the modelling of NGC3998 (a 1e9 solar mass black hole at that Eddington fraction) by Nemmen et al (2014). At a redshift of 0.1 (the maximum redshift of our targets) this luminosity corresponds to a 3.1mm flux density of 220 microJy.
As detailed in other science goals, our primary detection band is at 1.3mm, where the combination of ADAF SED and ALMA sensitivity is optimised. At 3.1mm, our primary goal is to determine the spectral shape of the ADAF SED, and in particular to exclude the possibility that the 1.3mm flux density arises from a jet-dominated model. For this, we aim for a signal-to-noise of 10 for these best-fit model-SED parameters. This is sufficient to provide a secure and accurate flux density measurement from which a spectral shape of the SED can be determined. We this target an rms sensitivity of 22 microJy/bm at 3.1mm.
Note that even if 1.3mm emission is up to an order of magnitude lower that the best-model predictions (due to variations in the model parameters) a 3-sigma non-detection to this 3.1mm sensitivity limit would still be sufficiently deep to rule out a jet-dominated origin for the 1.3mm emission.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band-6, RA~10, radio AGN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal is for Band-6 continuum imaging of 2 low-excitation radio galaxies, to directly detect thermal emission from the hot accretion flow. The aim is to determine the continuum flux density, and to compare these as a function of radio jet power (also with 5 other sources in a separate science goal). The required sensitivity is estimated to provide a S/N~20. The sources will be unresolved.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our focus is on continuum observations, and therefore we propose to use the low spectral resolution TDM mode. As such, the data rate is relatively low, and no further averaging is required (or desired).

The angular scale of the hot accretion disk around these AGN will be unresolved with ALMA. We aim for a moderately high angular resolution, to avoid any contamination from any thermal emission from extended dust in the galaxies, whilst avoiding angular resolutions so high that the calibration overhead begins to increase significantly. 0.5 arcsec resoluton (few hundred parsec at these redshifts) offers an ideal compromise, and is a resolution that can be matched at all three observing frequencies that we propose. The relevant array configurations are also scheduled when our targets would be night-time targets, increasing the likelihood of suitable observing conditions.

Estimates of the synchrotron luminosity associated with the thermal electron population of the ADAF have been made by many authors. Figure 1 of Yuan & Narayan (2014) shows example SEDs for best-model parameters (of disk viscosity, magnetic pressure, ion-to-electron energy transfer efficiency, and efficiency of disk winds). They indicate that for a black hole of 2e9 solar masses, accreting with a bolometric luminosity of 1e-4 of the Eddington luminosity (the properties of our tartgets) then the expected nu-L_nu is 3e40 erg/s at 1.3mm. This is in line with the results from the modelling of NGC3998 (a 1e9 solar mass black hole at that Eddington fraction) by Nemmen et al (2014). At a redshift of 0.1 (the maximum redshift of our targets) this luminosity corresponds to a 1.3mm flux density of 550 microJy.
The 1.3mm band is where the combination of ADAF SED and ALMA sensitivity lead to optimal detectability. We aim for a signal-to-noise of 20 in this frequency band for these best-fit model-SED parameters. This is sufficient to provide a secure and accurate flux density measurement for these parameters, whilst ensuring that we will obtain a detection (or extremely sensitive upper limit) even if ADAF luminosity is up to an order of magnitude lower due to variations in the model parameters. We thus target an rms sensitivity of 27.5 micro-Jy/bm.

We thus target an rms sensitivity of 27.5 micro-Jy/bm.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band-7, RA~10, radio AGN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal is for Band-7 continuum imaging of 2 low-excitation radio galaxies, to directly detect thermal emission from the hot accretion flow. The aim is to determine the continuum flux density, and to compare these as a function of radio jet power (also with 5 other sources in a separate science goal). The required sensitivity is estimated to provide a S/N~10. The sources will be unresolved.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our focus is on continuum observations, and therefore we propose to use the low spectral resolution TDM mode. As such, the data rate is relatively low, and no further averaging is required (or desired).

The angular scale of the hot accretion disk around these AGN will be unresolved with ALMA. We aim for a moderately high angular resolution, to avoid any contamination from any thermal emission from extended dust in the galaxies, whilst avoiding angular resolutions so high that the calibration overhead begins to increase significantly. 0.5 arcsec resoluton (few hundred parsec at these redshifts) offers an ideal compromise, and is a resolution that can be matched at all three observing frequencies that we propose. The relevant array configurations are also scheduled when our targets would be night-time targets, increasing the likelihood of suitable observing conditions.

Figure 1 of Yuan & Narayan (2014) shows example SEDs for best-model parameters (of disk viscosity, magnetic pressure, ion-to-electron energy transfer efficiency, and efficiency of disk winds). They indicate that for a black hole of 2e9 solar masses, accreting with a bolometric luminosity of 1e-4 of the Eddington luminosity (the properties of our tartgets) then the expected nu-L_nu is 5e40 erg/s at 850-microns. This is in line with the results from the modelling of NGC3998 (a 1e9 solar mass black hole at that Eddington fraction) by Nemmen et al (2014). At a redshift of 0.1 (the maximum redshift of our targets) this luminosity corresponds to an 850-micron flux density of 550 microJy.
As detailed in other science goals, our primary detection band is at 1.3mm, where the combination of ADAF SED and ALMA sensitivity is optimised. At 850-microns, our primary goal is to determine the spectral shape of the ADAF SED. In combination with the 3.1mm data point, this will confirm an ADAF origin for the 1.3mm emission. For this, we aim for a signal-to-noise of 10 for these best-fit model-SED parameters. This is sufficient to provide a secure and accurate flux density measurement from which a spectral shape of the SED can be determined. We this target an rms sensitivity of 55 micro-Jy/bm at 850-microns.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: When gas accretes onto black holes at low fractions of the Eddington rate, it does so through a geometrically thick, advection-dominated accretion flow (ADAF). These ADAFs are radiatively inefficient, but generate powerful outflows, especially bipolar radio jets. Mechanical energy feedback from these radio jets is now well-established to play a crucial AGN-feedback role in massive galaxies. However, the physical mechanisms by which the radio jets are launched remain poorly understood, as does the issue of whether the jet energy arises primarily from the rotational energy of the black hole or that of the accretion flow. In this proposal we aim to use ALMA to study a sample of seven massive nearby AGN, of the same black hole mass and radiative luminosity, but spanning three orders of magnitude in radio jet power. We will directly measure the synchrotron luminosity of the thermal electrons in the ADAF, and investigate how this varies with jet power. By comparison with ADAF models, we will determine which critical properties the jet power depends upon (black hole spin, wind-production efficiency, etc) and hence shed light on how radio jets are launched.
